comment_data.body: can it put the operators at the start instead of end? that is our usual style (and is preferrable imo), unless I missed something.

here's an example where ":" at the start is much more readable. one has to go to the end of the line to see where this `false` is coming from. Of course, I only mention this if it can be automated, else it's moot.

```suggestion
                                        : false));
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -474,7 +474,8 @@ static int nlua_wait(lua_State *lstate)
                             (int)timeout,
                             got_int || (is_function ? nlua_wait_condition(lstate,
                                                                           &pcall_status,
-                                                                          &callback_result) : false));
+                                                                          &callback_result) :
+                                        false));

comment_regular_data.body: Why has the line breaking between function parameters become so strange?

> @micheleCTDE any ideas?

Hi @dundargoc,
I read through the comments. Are you asking about the ternary operator placing or about function splitting logic?

Line splitting is a complex topic. We often had a number of problems with line splitting:
1.  a situation where long lines were split on open parenthesis of a function without parameters. 
2. bugs in the logic (and tests!) that resulted in splitting not obeying the code width rule.
3. split affected by indentation level, which sometimes resulted in the split being near the beginning of the line and sometimes being near the end of the line.
4. when some options were set, functions were split on arguments only instead of evaluating priority of tokens.

We have tried to address that and make line splitting a bit more stable in the way it behaves, trying to split on function on a argument's comma when possible and fix the bug described in 2. It is far from perfect of course and there is more work required because of the order between line splitting and indentation in the code.

With that said, if you can point out some specific examples, I am happy to have a look in coming days. Best would be to log an issue on uncrustify with the example.

For the ternary operation, you should be able to use `pos_conditional = lead` to get the `?` and `:` in front of the remaininig part of the code.

> With that said, if you can point out some specific examples, I am happy to have a look in coming days

Are the splitting/indentation changes that I see in this PR the only affected areas in neovim codebase?

> > With that said, if you can point out some specific examples, I am happy to have a look in coming days
> 
> Are the splitting/indentation changes that I see in this PR the only affected areas in neovim codebase?

I think yes.

Ok, I will use this PR for examples.
At a first look, some splits seems awkward and will need to be analized.. Some others are a consequence of fixing point 2.: you can see some of the original lines that got changed were longer than 100 characters (which is the code width limit in the config) and uncrustify is now splitting the lines.

Can you as a team live with the awkward splitting of those instances for the time being? I will definitely look into those problems, also because I have seen similar ones in our code base too (that's the "need more work" part that I mentioned in the previous comment).

> Can you as a team live with the awkward splitting of those instances for the time being?

No worries, this is not an urgent matter at all.

I don't mind creating issues for uncrustify with a minimal example.

Thank you for all your work :)

> I don't mind creating issues for uncrustify with a minimal example

Great, that's perfect :+1:

> Thank you for all your work :)

Likewise, thanks to all neovim team for your work, neovim is my daily workhorse for pretty much everything :slightly_smiling_face:
This PR is becoming too big. I will split the ternary/clint into another PR and only focus on the version bump here: https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/26103
